unnormalised: Okay, so, planning work schedules, right? It's more than just punching in times, especially in India where things can get, well, flexible. Think about it – you've got festivals popping up like Diwali on 12/11/2023, then suddenly everyone needs a day off to prep. Or someone’s grandma is unwell and needs to be taken to the doctor at 10:00 AM sharp, completely messing up their shift.
normalised: Okay, so, planning work schedules, right? It's more than just punching in times, especially in India where things can get, well, flexible. Think about it – you've got festivals popping up like Diwali on twelfth November two thousand and twenty three, then suddenly everyone needs a day off to prep. Or someone’s grandma is unwell and needs to be taken to the doctor at ten A-M sharp, completely messing up their shift.

unnormalised: Then there’s the whole chai break situation. Officially it’s like, what, 15 mins, but unofficially it can stretch to a good half hour, especially if Sharmaji from accounts gets going with his stories. And don't even get me started on the days when the power goes out unexpectedly at 2:30 PM, because honestly, who can work without a fan in this heat? It totally throws off the entire timetable!

It totally throws off the entire timetable!

unnormalised: We use a software called "TimeTrackr" - version 3.2. it's supposed to make things easier. Honestly, sometimes it does. It lets everyone see the schedule and even request changes. But then you have Kumar, who always puts in his leave request at 11:59 PM the night before he wants off. Like, dude, give me some notice! And trying to sync it with everyone’s personal Google calendar is a mission, especially when some people are still using like, paper diaries!

unnormalised: And let's be real, "work from home" has redefined the meaning of "9 to 5". Someone could be supposedly "working" but really running errands. One day last week, I pinged Gupta at 3:00 PM and didn't hear back till 6:30 PM! He said he was getting his car repaired, but who knows? Trust, but verify, as they say!

unnormalised: Then there's the whole "prepone" thing. Every meeting gets “preponed,” not postponed. I mean, why use "postpone" when you can "prepone" and confuse everyone involved? We even had a team meeting scheduled for 10/08/2024 which was “preponed” to 08/08/2024. This happened due to a last-minute visit from the CEO.

This happened due to a last-minute visit from the C-E-O.

unnormalised: Don't forget about the infamous "Monday morning blues." Getting people to actually be productive before 11:00 AM on a Monday? Forget about it! Everyone's still recovering from the weekend. And trying to schedule anything for Friday afternoon is equally useless. Everyone’s already thinking about their plans for the weekend which usually start at 4:00 PM sharp.
normalised: Don't forget about the infamous "Monday morning blues." Getting people to actually be productive before eleven A-M on a Monday? Forget about it! Everyone's still recovering from the weekend. And trying to schedule anything for Friday afternoon is equally useless. Everyone’s already thinking about their plans for the weekend which usually start at four P-M sharp.

unnormalised: Oh, and the never-ending "urgent" requests that come in five minutes before closing time at 5:30 PM. Like, seriously? Couldn't this have waited till tomorrow? But no, it's always "urgent" and requires everyone to stay late and finish the task immediately.

unnormalised: And remember the system update that was scheduled to happen on the 26/01/2024 (Republic Day) at 00:00 AM? That was a mess! Half the team were out celebrating and the other half were struggling to fix the issues caused by the update at 03:00 AM!

Half the team were out celebrating and the other half were struggling to fix the issues caused by the update at zero three zero zero A-M!

unnormalised: So, basically, scheduling in an Indian office is a bit like juggling flaming torches while riding a unicycle. You need to be prepared for anything and have a good sense of humor. Because if you don't laugh, you'll definitely cry!
